title: 115_s184
content: The Act titled "No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion and Abortion Insurance Full Disclosure Act of 2017" prohibits taxpayer-funded abortions and clarifies the application of this prohibition under the Affordable Care Act. It includes sections on prohibiting federally funded abortions and specifying the disclosure requirements for health plan coverage of abortion and premium surcharges. SEC. 101 of the Act adds a new chapter to Title 1, United States Code, prohibiting taxpayer-funded abortions. Sec. 301 prohibits federal funds from being used for abortions. Sec. 302 prohibits funding for health plans that cover abortion. Other sections address limitations on federal facilities, use of non-federal funds for coverage, and treatment of abortions related to rape, incest, or preserving the mother's life. Sec. 302 prohibits federal funding for health benefits plans that cover abortion. Sec. 303 limits abortion services in federal facilities and by federal employees. Sec. 304 clarifies that individuals, entities, or states can still purchase separate abortion coverage. Sec. 304 clarifies that individuals, entities, or states can purchase separate abortion coverage using non-Federal funds without restrictions on the source of payment. Sec. 306 states that the chapter does not affect other Federal laws limiting funds for abortion coverage. Sec. 307 clarifies that the chapter does not apply to treating complications from abortions, regardless of legality. The chapter does not affect other Federal laws limiting funds for abortion coverage. It also does not apply to treating complications from abortions, regardless of legality. Abortion is allowed in cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is in danger. "In this chapter, any funds appropriated by Federal law will also include approved amounts within the District of Columbia budget. The term 'Federal Government' now encompasses the government of the District of Columbia." SEC. 102. AMENDMENT TO TABLE OF CHAPTERS. The table of chapters for title 1, United States Code, is amended by adding a new item: "Prohibiting taxpayer funded abortions - 301". TITLE II--APPLICATION UNDER THE AFFORDABLE CARE ACT SEC. 201. CLARIFYING APPLICATION OF PROHIBITION TO PREMIUM CREDITS AND COST-SHARING REDUCTIONS UNDER ACA. The amendment disallows refundable credits and cost-sharing reductions for health plans covering abortions, unless separate abortion coverage is purchased or offered. The amendment allows individuals to purchase separate abortion coverage or a health plan that includes abortion, as long as no tax credit is provided for the premiums. Non-Federal health insurance issuers can also offer separate abortion coverage. The amendment allows individuals to purchase separate abortion coverage or a health plan that includes abortion, as long as no tax credit is provided for the premiums. Non-Federal health insurance issuers can also offer separate abortion coverage. The amendment disallows the small employer health insurance expense credit for plans that include coverage for abortion. The amendment excludes health plans with abortion coverage from being considered qualified health plans. Employers can still purchase separate abortion coverage for their employees. The amendment allows for separate coverage for abortions in health plans, as long as no employer contributions eligible for tax credits are used to pay for it. Non-Federal health insurance issuers can offer plans with abortion coverage, but it cannot be funded by employer contributions eligible for tax credits. The amendment allows separate coverage for abortions in health plans, ensuring that no federal funds are used for such coverage. The amendments to the United States Code apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2017, and plan years beginning after that date. SEC. 202. Revision of notice requirements for disclosure of health plan coverage of abortion and abortion premium surcharges. The amendment to section 1303(b) of Public Law 111-148 requires disclosure of coverage for certain services by qualified health plans at the time of enrollment and in marketing materials. The amendment requires disclosure of abortion surcharges in qualified health plans, separate from the premium, effective more than 30 days after enactment.
